import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
source.e740c43a:
sns.lineplot(x = Salary, y = exp)
plt.title("Salaries of data scientist according to their experiences")
plt.xlabel("Exp")
plt.ylabel("Salary")
plt.show()
source.bd95941b:
exp = [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10]

Prog_Salary = [8000, 15000, 20000, 25000, 30000, 35000, 40000, 50000]

Other_Salary = [1000, 18000, 25000, 30000, 35000, 40000, 42000, 60000]

sns.lineplot(exp, Prog_Salary)
sns.lineplot(exp, Other_Salary)

plt.title("Salaries of Programmer and other jobs according to their experiences")
plt.xlabel("Exp")
plt.ylabel("Salaries")

plt.legend("Programmers", "Other Jobs")
plt.show()

source.42dcb53d:

source.a8cd0432:
plt.figure(figsize=(20, 7))

sns.lineplot(data=tour, x="year", y="passengers", hue="month")

plt.title("No of Passengers on monthly basis")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Passengers")

plt.show()
source.a088f299:
exp = [1, 3, 5, 7, 9]

Salary = [10000, 20000, 30000, 50000, 70000]

gender = ["Man", "Woman", "Man", "Woman", "Woman"]

sns.barplot(x=exp, y=Salary, hue=gender)

plt.title("Salaries by gener")
plt.show()
source.3b4993e6:
sns.barplot(x=exp, y=Salary, orient='h')
plt.title("Salaries of workers")

plt.show()
source.87f9e7f5:

sns.lineplot(x=exp, y=Salary)

plt.title("Salaries of different Workers")

plt.xlabel("Exp")
plt.ylabel("Salaries")

plt.show()

source.9502f9e3:
# Seaborn
**Seaborn is a Python data visualization library based on matplotlib. It provides a high-level interface for drawing attractive and informative statistical graphics.**
source.f7e682a7: **First We will plot programmer Salaries with their experiences. We will firsr use line function.**
